item.title: Reflecting on Pope Leo’s call for an unarmed peace for a wounded world
item.description:
Reflecting on Pope Leo XIV’s first World Day of Peace message, Marie Dennis, the director of Pax Christi’s Catholic Institute for Nonviolence, highlights a vision of peace that is unarmed, disarming, humble, and persevering. In a world marked by fear and conflict, she points to Gospel nonviolence as a concrete, hopeful path already being lived in communities across the globe.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Reflecting on Pope Leo XIV’s first World Day of Peace message, Marie Dennis, the director of Pax Christi’s Catholic Institute for Nonviolence, highlights a vision of peace that is unarmed, disarming, humble, and persevering. In a world marked by fear and conflict, she points to Gospel nonviolence as a concrete, hopeful path already being lived in communities across the globe.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-12/marie-dennis-pax-christi-pope-leo-message-world-day-peace.html)

item.title: 2025 in numbers: Over 3 million faithful visited the Vatican
item.description:
Data released by the Prefecture of the Papal Household shows that over 250,000 people attended papal audiences and liturgical celebrations in the Vatican in the period to April. Following the election of Pope Leo XIV in early May, nearly three million faithful took part in Masses and ceremonies.

item.title: Olympics watchdog failed to close abuse case against gymnastics coach: report
item.description: A new investigation has found that months before Sean Gardner's arrest on allegations of installing cameras in a girls’ gym bathroom, the American was willing to accept a lifetime ban from coaching gymnastics as part of a deal where he would admit to the abuse, according to three people involved with U.S. SafeSport and its handling of the case.
item.source:markdown:
![Carly Patterson vaults in the air during the U.S. Gymnastics Championships on June 5, 2004 at the Gaylord Entertainment Center in Nashville, Tennessee. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4d4d2201-4855-4be6-96bc-e8081593498d,1767114425791/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%2820%2C0%2C1139%2C640%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A new investigation has found that months before Sean Gardner's arrest on allegations of installing cameras in a girls’ gym bathroom, the American was willing to accept a lifetime ban from coaching gymnastics as part of a deal where he would admit to the abuse, according to three people involved with U.S. SafeSport and its handling of the case.

item.title: LIVE: General Assembly decides on 2026 UN budget
item.description: Follow our live coverage as the General Assembly and its Fifth Committee meet today to finalize negotiations and vote on the United Nations’ regular budget for 2026. item.title: Guinea closes 2025 Jubilee Year with an appeal to citizens - embrace civic responsibility
item.description:
The Jubilee Year for the particular Churches concluded worldwide on Sunday, 28 December 2025. In Guinea, however, the Church anticipated this conclusion by one day due to the national electoral calendar. Between spiritual fervour, homage to the pioneers of faith in the country, and a call to civic responsibility, Archbishop Vincent Coulibaly alluded to a church continuing its mission for the next 25 years and beyond.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Jubilee Year for the particular Churches concluded worldwide on Sunday, 28 December 2025. In Guinea, however, the Church anticipated this conclusion by one day due to the national electoral calendar. Between spiritual fervour, homage to the pioneers of faith in the country, and a call to civic responsibility, Archbishop Vincent Coulibaly alluded to a church continuing its mission for the next 25 years and beyond.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-12/guinea-closes-2025-jubilee-year-with-an-appeal-to-citizens-emb.html)

item.title: U.S. Coast Guard chases Venezuelan oil tanker attempting to claim Russian protection
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard is still in pursuit of an oil tanker over a week after they first tried to intercept the ship. U.S. officials said the tanker now has a painted Russian flag on its side in an attempt to draw protection from Moscow. This is the latest in President Trump's pressure campaign on Venezuela after he indicted that the United States has "hit" a dock facility along a shore.
item.source:markdown:
![An oil tanker is pictured at a dock. In the foreground, palm trees line a beach.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7961169b-2b09-45a7-8541-a6d2a0a3ac70,1767075230957/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C292%2C5616%2C3159%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Coast Guard is still in pursuit of an oil tanker over a week after they first tried to intercept the ship. U.S. officials said the tanker now has a painted Russian flag on its side in an attempt to draw protection from Moscow. This is the latest in President Trump's pressure campaign on Venezuela after he indicted that the United States has "hit" a dock facility along a shore.

item.title: After years on their back foot, here's why Democrats are feeling good about 2026
item.description: For much of the last two years, the U.S. Democratic Party has been on its back foot, enduring painful electoral defeats to an omnipresent Republican opponent while grappling with a troubling decline in voter registration and a listless party base. But in the closing days of 2025, the political pendulum appears to be swinging in their direction.
item.source:markdown:
![New Jersey Democratic gubernatorial candidate Mikie Sherrill celebrates after winning a tightly contested race for New Jersey governor.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b85380ce-0816-4098-96fb-e386cd419bbf,1767055998298/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C3695%2C2078%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
For much of the last two years, the U.S. Democratic Party has been on its back foot, enduring painful electoral defeats to an omnipresent Republican opponent while grappling with a troubling decline in voter registration and a listless party base. But in the closing days of 2025, the political pendulum appears to be swinging in their direction.

item.title: 'Embarrassing situation' over limited U2 tickets in 1987
item.description: A telex sent from an Irish official based in Boston in April 1987, stating that a limit of ten complimentary tickets per U2 show in America, "puts us in an embarrassing situation" reveals the level of interest in the band's massively successful Joshua Tree tour there.

item.title: Pope Leo sends aid to Ukraine for Holy Family Sunday

item.title: Much of Kyiv without heat after deadly Russian airstrikes
item.description:
Authorities say a third of Kyiv is without heating after a deadly Russian drone and missile barrage on the Ukrainian capital cut off power supplies, leaving hundreds of thousands of people facing freezing temperatures. The attack, which reportedly killed at least one person and wounded two dozen others, prompted nearby Poland to scramble fighter jets and close civilian airports.

item.title: Russia is about to start staging plays at the Mariupol theatre it bombed
item.description: Russian state media reported that the theatre is slated to officially reopen on Dec. 25, and that plays will start being staged there at some point in the new year. Russian occupation authorities have renamed it the Mariupol Republican Order of the Badge of Honour Russian Drama Theatre, and on its website write that the theatre is being reborn, like the entire city of Mariupol.
item.source:markdown:
![A Christmas tree stands in a square near the newly rebuilt theatre in Mariupol which was destroyed in an airstrike on March 16, 2022. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/d844add5-60c6-4849-85d5-71298fb0a0d4,1766095544721/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C206%2C5754%2C3236%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Russian state media reported that the theatre is slated to officially reopen on Dec. 25, and that plays will start being staged there at some point in the new year. item.description: Below the long-isolated and neglected Neapolitan neighbourhood of Rione Sanità, a vast underground network of ancient burial chambers remained mostly forgotten for centuries. Today, a social co-operative ihas turned the cultural heritage of the Catacombs of San Gennaro into local jobs, skills and a steady draw of tourists.
item.source:markdown:
![People walk around in cavernous underground catacombs. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f8bbfe48-0f5e-4e9e-818d-f7f547eea629,1766459415638/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C228%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: UN celebrates 10 years of progress in youth, peace and security agenda
item.description: The UN has long been at the forefront of efforts to involve young people in decision-making, and the last decade has seen significant progress, thanks to the adoption of a Security Council resolution on youth, peace and security which led to widespread changes in the ways that the voices of young people are not just heard, but also incorporated in peace plans and policies.

item.title: Industrialisation without destruction: A UN blueprint for the future
item.description: Since the 19th century, industrialisation has had a transformative effect on the world, both positive and negative. It has created jobs and lifted millions out of poverty. But it has also had devastating consequences; destroying ecosystems, polluting the air, and driving the climate crisis that threatens to make large parts of the planet uninhabitable.
item.source:markdown: Since the 19th century, industrialisation has had a transformative effect on the world, both positive and negative. It has created jobs and lifted millions out of poverty. But it has also had devastating consequences; destroying ecosystems, polluting the air, and driving the climate crisis that threatens to make large parts of the planet uninhabitable.

item.title: Parkland school shooting survivor confronts trauma again during Brown University shooting
item.description: It’s rare for anyone to say they’ve lived through one mass shooting, let alone two. But at just 20 years old, Zoe Weissman now belongs to a growing club that no one would ever choose to join. The sophomore says she was in her dorm room on Brown University’s campus Dec. 13, when she got a frantic phone call from a friend. Weissman says she suspected right away that there’d been a shooting.
item.source:markdown:
![Zoe Weissman, 20 survived the Parkland high school massacre in 2018 and last Saturday, survived another mass shooting again, this time as a student at Brown University in Rhode Island.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5ae55569-402e-4b5b-ab56-938bad48909e,1766529712652/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C106%2C2048%2C1152%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
It’s rare for anyone to say they’ve lived through one mass shooting, let alone two. But at just 20 years old, Zoe Weissman now belongs to a growing club that no one would ever choose to join. The sophomore says she was in her dorm room on Brown University’s campus Dec. 13, when she got a frantic phone call from a friend. Weissman says she suspected right away that there’d been a shooting.

item.title: LIVE: Security Council meets on Venezuela, Iran, Somalia
item.description: The Security Council convened earlier today for a packed agenda, adopting a resolution extending the authorisation of the African Union support mission in Somalia (AUSSOM) and hearing a briefing on Iran and the implementation of resolution 2231, which endorsed the 2015 nuclear deal known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). Members are set to reconvene at 3 pm for an emergency meeting requested by Venezuela, amid heightened tensions between Caracas and Washington. Assistant Secretary-General for Political Affairs Khaled Khiari is expected to brief ambassadors. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council convened earlier today for a packed agenda, adopting a resolution extending the authorisation of the African Union support mission in Somalia (AUSSOM) and hearing a briefing on Iran and the implementation of resolution 2231, which endorsed the 2015 nuclear deal known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). Members are set to reconvene at 3 pm for an emergency meeting requested by Venezuela, amid heightened tensions between Caracas and Washington. Assistant Secretary-General for Political Affairs Khaled Khiari is expected to brief ambassadors. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Nigeria: Kontagora’s Christmas gift – the return of its abducted children
item.description:
Diocese of Kontagora’s Catholic Bishop, Bulus Dauwa Yohanna, on Monday confirmed to Vatican News the release of 130 students and staff abducted from St. Mary’s Primary and Secondary School in Papiri on 21 November. The children and staff were part of an original 315 victims forcibly taken by gunmen from the school in the night.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Diocese of Kontagora’s Catholic Bishop, Bulus Dauwa Yohanna, on Monday confirmed to Vatican News the release of 130 students and staff abducted from St. Mary’s Primary and Secondary School in Papiri on 21 November. The children and staff were part of an original 315 victims forcibly taken by gunmen from the school in the night.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-12/nigeria-kontagora-s-christmas-gift-the-return-of-its-abducted.html)

item.title: International Swimming League targets 2026 relaunch after COVID, war disruptions
item.description: The International Swimming League plans to relaunch as soon as 2026 after a three-year hiatus, betting a reshaped commercial model, stable backing and momentum from the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics can sustain a global, team-based competition in one of the Games' marquee sports.

The International Swimming League plans to relaunch as soon as 2026 after a three-year hiatus, betting a reshaped commercial model, stable backing and momentum from the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics can sustain a global, team-based competition in one of the Games' marquee sports.

item.description: The war in Sudan is entering a deadlier phase, the United Nations has warned, as intensified fighting in the Kordofan region, mounting civilian casualties from drone strikes and growing risks of regional spillover push the conflict toward the 1,000-day mark.

item.title: LIVE: Security Council meets on escalating violence in Sudan
item.description: Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are set brief the Security Council this afternoon as members meet to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan, where intensified fighting – including in the Kordofan region – has driven widespread civilian harm and displacement. The region has seen a sharp escalation, including a deadly drone attack on a UN peacekeeping base that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers. The meeting was requested by Sudan and Transitional Prime Minister, Kamil Eltayeb Idris, is expected to attend. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.
item.source:markdown: Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are set brief the Security Council this afternoon as members meet to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan, where intensified fighting – including in the Kordofan region – has driven widespread civilian harm and displacement. The region has seen a sharp escalation, including a deadly drone attack on a UN peacekeeping base that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers. The meeting was requested by Sudan and Transitional Prime Minister, Kamil Eltayeb Idris, is expected to attend. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Pope: A more missionary Curia must bear witness to communion in a divided world
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets his closest collaborators for the exchange of traditional Christmas greetings. item.title: Zanzibar Cup 2026 aims to build on global fraternity and peace
item.description:
The fifth edition of the international kitesurfing event is set to take place on 7 February 2026 in Zanzibar, Tanzania, with the deadline for participation on 6 January. The competition aims to build on social, cultural, and humanitarian dimensions that convey a strong message of peace and fellowship, in addition to good sportsmanship and an exciting race in a stunningly beautiful part of the world.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo XIV: May all children of the world live in peace!
item.description:
Reflecting on the figure of Saint Joseph on the Fourth Sunday of Advent, Pope Leo XIV recalls the virtues he lived of piety, charity, and mercy that educate the heart to encounter Christ and our brothers and sisters. As we await the birth of the Saviour, he encourages us to be "a welcoming manger, a hospitable home, a sign of God’s presence" and that all children may live in peace.

Read all

item.title: Ukraine President sceptical over trilateral peace talks amid deadly clashes
item.description:
Ukraine's president says the United States has proposed a format for peace talks that would place Ukraine and Russia at the same table, but he doubts such a meeting would bring real progress. Zelenskyy spoke as a Russian missile strike on port infrastructure in Odesa in southern Ukraine killed at least eight people and wounded twenty-seven, while Ukrainian drones hit several Russian targets.

item.title: Somalis say foreign ships are stealing their fish, and it's fuelling a piracy resurgence
item.description: Piracy off the coast of Somalia is back in the headlines after European Union naval forces seized an Iranian fishing vessel last month that Somali pirates used to briefly hijack a Malta-flagged tanker carrying gasoline from India to South Africa. Fishermen insist the bigger problem in the region is that foreign vessels are fishing in waters intended for locals, harming their livelihoods.
item.source:markdown:
![A man stands on a rock by the ocean with a fishing rod.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1e16f609-965b-4a97-9bbf-37b75dc54675,1765951344335/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C221%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Piracy off the coast of Somalia is back in the headlines after European Union naval forces seized an Iranian fishing vessel last month that Somali pirates used to briefly hijack a Malta-flagged tanker carrying gasoline from India to South Africa. Fishermen insist the bigger problem in the region is that foreign vessels are fishing in waters intended for locals, harming their livelihoods.

item.title: Fear, death and hope in a city under the shadows of a Mexican cartel war
item.description: Fear and violence permeate Culiacán, Sinaloa, and its surrounding area in northwestern Mexico. The sun-seared state capital, with a population of a little more than one million, is also known as the cradle of the Sinaloa cartel, one of the most powerful organized crime groups in the world, which has fallen into a vicious civil war.
item.source:markdown:
![Three police officers walk up a driveway with caution tape strung across the entrance.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/d030d2b4-d943-42ed-a0e8-2bcdc8f11673,1766171225357/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28356%2C698%2C3675%2C2067%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Fear and violence permeate Culiacán, Sinaloa, and its surrounding area in northwestern Mexico. item.title: Canada's growing profile in Antarctic research may get a boost with expedition in 2026
item.description: Canada's growing profile in Antarctic research may get another boost in early 2026, as the commander of the Royal Canadian Navy confirms a possible second expedition is in the works, in collaboration with the Chilean navy. item.description: A woman who was raped by her former partner has said she is "speaking out because I want to turn my pain into purpose" after he was jailed for eight years.
item.source:markdown: A woman who was raped by her former partner has said she is "speaking out because I want to turn my pain into purpose" after he was jailed for eight years.

item.title: U.S. imposes sanctions on family and associates of Venezuela's Maduro and his wife
item.description: The United States on Friday imposed sanctions on family members and associates of Nicolás Maduro and his wife, as Washington ratchets up pressure on the Venezuelan president.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman walks past a mural depicting Venezuela President Nicolas Maduro](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96ae1cd2-5cdb-4a7a-b524-ef460a366190,1766176899247/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C391%2C4585%2C2579%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The United States on Friday imposed sanctions on family members and associates of Nicolás Maduro and his wife, as Washington ratchets up pressure on the Venezuelan president.

item.title: Senior FF TDs reject 'top-down autocratic style' politics
item.description: Fianna Fáil TDs Seán Ó Fearghaíl, Willie O'Dea and Pat 'the Cope' Gallagher have issued a statement following Tuesday's Fianna Fáil parliamentary party meeting that discussed the report into the party's disastrous presidential election campaign.
item.source:markdown: Fianna Fáil TDs Seán Ó Fearghaíl, Willie O'Dea and Pat 'the Cope' Gallagher have issued a statement following Tuesday's Fianna Fáil parliamentary party meeting that discussed the report into the party's disastrous presidential election campaign.

item.title: Woman would be alive if partner was listened to - family
item.description: The family of a woman killed by her partner while he was suffering a relapse of a schizoaffective disorder have said they believe she would be alive today if her partner had been properly listened to.
item.source:markdown: The family of a woman killed by her partner while he was suffering a relapse of a schizoaffective disorder have said they believe she would be alive today if her partner had been properly listened to.

item.title: Pasolini: May the Church foster encounter as she sets out to know God
item.description:
“The universality of salvation: A hope without conditions” is the theme of the third Advent meditation, delivered Friday morning in the Paul VI Hall in the presence of the Pope. In his sermon, Fr Roberto Pasolini, the Preacher of the Papal Household focuses on the attitude of the Magi, who boldly dared to open themselves to the unknown.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.description:
In this week’s news from the Eastern Churches, produced in collaboration with L’Œuvre d’Orient: Christians in Damascus prepare for Christmas with prayer and remembrance at the Church of Mar Elias, Iraqi faithful celebrate the much-loved feast of the martyrs Mar Behnam and Sara, and the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church launches Svitlyk, a new YouTube channel bringing faith-filled content to children.

item.title: Manhattan Peanuts objects to Luas extension to Finglas
item.description: A food company has begun legal action against the extension of the Luas to Finglas in west Dublin.
item.source:markdown: A food company has begun legal action against the extension of the Luas to Finglas in west Dublin.

item.title: Ryan Tubridy to launch YouTube series after Virgin exit
item.description: Ryan Tubridy has finished his Virgin Radio UK programme today, with the UK broadcasting company News Broadcasting announcing a host of new projects for the presenter next year.
item.source:markdown: Ryan Tubridy has finished his Virgin Radio UK programme today, with the UK broadcasting company News Broadcasting announcing a host of new projects for the presenter next year.

item.title: Man jailed for life for 'brutal' murder of brother-in-law
item.description: A 44-year-old man who shot dead his brother-in-law with a submachine gun in the front garden of the victim's home in Ballyfermot, west Dublin, almost four years ago has been sentenced to life in prison.
item.source:markdown: A 44-year-old man who shot dead his brother-in-law with a submachine gun in the front garden of the victim's home in Ballyfermot, west Dublin, almost four years ago has been sentenced to life in prison.

item.title: Gaza no longer has famine, says global hunger monitor
item.description: There is no longer famine in Gaza, a global hunger monitor has said, after access for humanitarian and commercial food deliveries improved following a fragile 10 October ceasefire in the war between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas.
item.source:markdown: There is no longer famine in Gaza, a global hunger monitor has said, after access for humanitarian and commercial food deliveries improved following a fragile 10 October ceasefire in the war between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas.

item.title: Parents jailed over multiple offences of child cruelty
item.description: The parents of six children who were subjected to almost daily physical and emotional abuse over a number of years have been sentenced at Castlebar Circuit Court in Mayo.
item.source:markdown: The parents of six children who were subjected to almost daily physical and emotional abuse over a number of years have been sentenced at Castlebar Circuit Court in Mayo.

item.title: Pope to young people: Make peace with someone this Christmas
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV greets several young members of the Italian Catholic Action, and invites them to make peace with somebody close to them before Christmas, emphasizing that peace is built starting from our daily relationships.

item.title: Ukraine says it has struck Russian 'shadow fleet' tanker
item.description: Ukraine said it has hit a Russian "shadow fleet" tanker with aerial drones in neutral waters of the Mediterranean Sea, its first strike in the sea in the nearly four-year war.
item.source:markdown: Ukraine said it has hit a Russian "shadow fleet" tanker with aerial drones in neutral waters of the Mediterranean Sea, its first strike in the sea in the nearly four-year war.

item.title: Sudan war: Kordofan’s El-Obeid ‘one or two steps’ away from being attacked
item.description: As fighting escalates in Sudan, “people are scared, people are fleeing their homes”, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Friday, noting that more than 50,000 people have been uprooted since late October in the Kordofans region alone.
item.source:markdown: As fighting escalates in Sudan, “people are scared, people are fleeing their homes”, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Friday, noting that more than 50,000 people have been uprooted since late October in the Kordofans region alone.

item.title: South Sudan: UN condemns killing of staff member in Wau, calls for swift investigation
item.description: The United Nations on Friday condemned the killing of a civilian staff member serving with its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), calling on the authorities to swiftly bring those responsible to justice.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations on Friday condemned the killing of a civilian staff member serving with its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), calling on the authorities to swiftly bring those responsible to justice.

item.title: Gaza famine pushed back, but millions still face hunger and malnutrition, UN says
item.description: Food security in Gaza has improved since the ceasefire declared in October, pushing back famine conditions, but the situation remains critical with more than three-quarters of the population still facing acute hunger and malnutrition, a new UN-backed analysis has found.
item.source:markdown: Food security in Gaza has improved since the ceasefire declared in October, pushing back famine conditions, but the situation remains critical with more than three-quarters of the population still facing acute hunger and malnutrition, a new UN-backed analysis has found.

item.title: UN urges calm in Bangladesh after killing of protest leader sparks unrest
item.description: The United Nations has urged calm in Bangladesh after the killing of a prominent youth protest leader sparked fresh unrest, raising concerns about political violence and the safety of civic space as the country prepares for elections early next year.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations has urged calm in Bangladesh after the killing of a prominent youth protest leader sparked fresh unrest, raising concerns about political violence and the safety of civic space as the country prepares for elections early next year.

item.title: Calming the mind and promoting global peace on World Meditation Day
item.description: Meditation, which has its roots in religious, yogic and secular traditions from various civilisations, calls for living in the present moment.
item.source:markdown: Meditation, which has its roots in religious, yogic and secular traditions from various civilisations, calls for living in the present moment.

item.title: World News in Brief: More UN staff detentions in Yemen, peacekeepers killed in Sudan sent home, attacks in Ukraine
item.description: The UN Secretary-General on Friday condemned the arbitrary detention of 10 more UN personnel by Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, warning that the growing crackdown is crippling humanitarian operations and putting millions of lives at risk.
item.source:markdown: The UN Secretary-General on Friday condemned the arbitrary detention of 10 more UN personnel by Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, warning that the growing crackdown is crippling humanitarian operations and putting millions of lives at risk.

item.title: Security Council renews DR Congo peacekeeping mission amid renewed M23 offensives in the east
item.description: The UN Security Council on Friday unanimously extended the mandate of the UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for another year, as fighting in the country’s east intensified amid renewed offensives by the M23 rebel group.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council on Friday unanimously extended the mandate of the UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for another year, as fighting in the country’s east intensified amid renewed offensives by the M23 rebel group.

item.title: Security Council hears of fading election prospects in Libya
item.description: The path to long-awaited elections in Libya is paved with complications but they can be overcome, the UN Special Representative for the country said on Friday in a briefing to the Security Council.
item.source:markdown: The path to long-awaited elections in Libya is paved with complications but they can be overcome, the UN Special Representative for the country said on Friday in a briefing to the Security Council.

item.title: Miss Finland accused of racism for pulling eyes back in photo — then MPs did it, too

item.title: Israel could be bringing back the death penalty — but only for Palestinians
item.description: While any debate over imposing the death penalty is bound to be emotional and contentious, Israel’s proposal to impose lethal punishment only on Palestinians makes new legislation before the Knesset especially egregious, say rights groups. item.title: Man suspected in Brown University shooting and MIT professor's killing found dead, officials say
item.description: A man suspected in the fatal shootings at Brown University and of a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor has been found dead in a New Hampshire storage facility after a five-day search that spanned several New England states, authorities said Thursday.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Argentinian layman, 11 Spanish martyrs to be beatified
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV authorises the promulgation of decrees relating to the upcoming beatification of nine seminarians, a priest, and a layman, martyrs during the Spanish Civil War; as well as an Argentine family man, Enrique Ernesto Shaw, an entrepreneur involved in various ecclesial works. As of today, Fra Berardo Atonna and Sister Domenica Caterina dello Spirito Santo, both Italian, and Joseph Panjikaran, an Indian priest, are recognized as venerable.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV authorises the promulgation of decrees relating to the upcoming beatification of nine seminarians, a priest, and a layman, martyrs during the Spanish Civil War; as well as an Argentine family man, Enrique Ernesto Shaw, an entrepreneur involved in various ecclesial works. As of today, Fra Berardo Atonna and Sister Domenica Caterina dello Spirito Santo, both Italian, and Joseph Panjikaran, an Indian priest, are recognized as venerable.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/argentinian-layman-11-spanish-martyrs-to-be-beatified.html)

item.title: EU finds more money for Ukraine, but fails to reach deal to release frozen Russian assets

European Union leaders have decided to borrow cash to loan 90 billion euros ($145 billion Cdn) to Ukraine to fund its defence against Russia for the next two years rather than use frozen Russian assets, sidestepping divisions over an unprecedented plan to finance Kyiv with Russian sovereign cash.

item.title: How Venezuelan crude could shake things up for Canadian producers
item.description: Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.
item.source:markdown:
![A pair of pumpjacks are bisected by a rainbow.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/72155439-8df1-4fcb-964f-3701acfbc1c7,1766070648146/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C78%2C2000%2C1125%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.

item.title: Pope Leo calls for an unarmed peace amid the threat of war
item.description:
In his Message for the 2026 World Day of Peace, Pope Leo XIV addresses the escalation of war, rearmament and fear in international relations, and reiterates the Church’s opposition to deterrence based on military force. He calls for disarmament, dialogue and the conversion of hearts as necessary conditions for a lasting and unarmed peace.

item.title: U.S. announces $11.1B weapons package for Taiwan, angering China
item.description: The United States on Wednesday approved $11.1 billion US in arms sales to Taiwan, the largest ever U.S. weapons package for the island which is under increasing military pressure from China.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Why is the U.K. rethinking puberty blockers?
item.description: Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts [https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts]
item.source:markdown:
![Abstract image of a burner on a stove](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b160fe9c-f2a8-490b-a969-72f55ff4bd73,1760988313788/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Today, an in-depth look at puberty blockers and their use on minors with gender dysphoria. These drugs have come under an enormous amount of scrutiny in recent years, with some questioning their benefits, safety and long-term impact. After banning the use of puberty blockers for gender treatment of people under 18, a new clinical trial in the U.K. aims to get to the bottom of those concerns. Azeen Ghorayshi is a science and gender reporter for the New York Times. She’ll parse through what we know and don’t know about the effects of blockers in minors, how this became a hugely divisive and politicized debate around the world, and whether this new trial could change our understanding. For transcripts of Front Burner, please visit: https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts \[https://www.cbc.ca/radio/frontburner/transcripts\]

item.title: Anti-Kremlin punk band Pussy Riot designated an extremist group by Russian court
item.description: The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.
item.source:markdown:
![A group of people with pink balaclavas are shown.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/edd3e46c-4232-4a2b-99a1-9391b836e902,1765826382207/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C229%2C4395%2C2472%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The Russian anti-Kremlin feminist punk band and art collective known as Pussy Riot was designated an extremist organization by a Moscow court on Monday, banning its activities inside Russia as part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices.

item.title: Ex-FG cllr jailed for theft of €172,000 from charity

item.title: Alessandro Gisotti named new President of the EBU Radio News Group
item.description:
The Deputy Editorial Director of Vatican Media, Alessandro Gisotti, succeeds German journalist Stephanie Pieper of Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg, as President of the EBU Radio News Group. “I am convinced that radio remains essential in the era of Artificial Intelligence because it offers reliable information and a connection with the community that algorithms cannot replace,” he says.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-12/alessandro-gisotti-ebu-radio-news-group-president.html)

item.title: Aid deprioritised as commercial goods flow into Gaza, UN warns
item.description: Humanitarian assistance in Gaza is being delayed because aid cargo is routinely deprioritised in favour of commercial goods, the UN’s aid coordination office (OCHA) warned on Monday, as winter storms continue to worsen already dire living conditions for displaced families.

item.title: Six peacekeepers laid to rest following deadly drone attack in Sudan

item.description: Gathered around the Security Council’s iconic horseshoe table, ambassadors were urged on Monday to find ways of working together – drawing lessons from past periods when, despite deep rivalry and distrust, the body was able to support UN leadership in steering the world away from catastrophe.

item.title: Living Ancestors:’ Voices of African Sisters are a testament of resilience
item.description:
Countless stories of courage go untold, but the book “Living Ancestors” emerges as a voice for the unseen, the unheard and the deeply faithful women who have shape Africa’s spiritual and social spaces through decades of consecrated service. This ground-breaking work has been brought to life by Sr. Mumbi Kigutha of the Sister of the Precious blood Dayton, Ohio, CPPS, offers a rare glimpse into their lived experiences.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Countless stories of courage go untold, but the book “Living Ancestors” emerges as a voice for the unseen, the unheard and the deeply faithful women who have shape Africa’s spiritual and social spaces through decades of consecrated service. This ground-breaking work has been brought to life by Sr. Mumbi Kigutha of the Sister of the Precious blood Dayton, Ohio, CPPS, offers a rare glimpse into their lived experiences.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-12/sisters-project-african-religious-resilience-living-ancestors.html)

item.title: Pope prays for victims of Sydney attack: ‘Enough with antisemitic violence!’
item.description:
Speaking with the groups that donated this year’s Vatican Christmas Tree and Nativity Scene, Pope Leo XIV highlights God’s closeness to humanity and calls for prayers for those who suffer on account of war and violence, especially the victims of Sunday’s terror attack on the Jewish community in Sydney, Australia.

Read all

item.title: Hamas says Israel killing commander threatens ceasefire
item.description: Israel's assassination of a senior Hamas commander threatens the viability of the Gaza ceasefire, the chief negotiator of the militant group has said, calling on US President Donald Trump to demand Israel comply with the terms of the truce.

item.title: Syria arrests 5 over suspected ties to deadly ambush of U.S., Syrian military convoy
item.description: Two U.S. army soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed by an attacker who targeted a convoy of American and Syrian forces before being shot dead. The Syrian Interior Ministry has described the attacker as a member of the Syrian security forces suspected of sympathizing with ISIS.

![A soldier mounts a flag atop of vehicle.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4fdc3684-3a1c-42a3-ba82-6f2f32ed14d5,1765746530276/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C285%2C5472%2C3078%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Two U.S. army soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed by an attacker who targeted a convoy of American and Syrian forces before being shot dead. The Syrian Interior Ministry has described the attacker as a member of the Syrian security forces suspected of sympathizing with ISIS.

item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Sunday voiced readiness to drop his country's bid to join NATO in exchange for Western security guarantees, but rejected the U.S. push for ceding territory to Russia as he held talks with U.S. envoys on ending the war.

item.title: Guterres condemns deadly attack on Hannukah celebration in Sydney

item.title: Dialogue is ‘not naïve – it’s necessary’ as global divisions deepen, UN Riyadh forum hears
item.description: The 11th Global Forum of the UN Alliance of Civilizations opened in Riyadh on Sunday with a blunt message for a world riven by distrust: dialogue is not a luxury – it’s a survival strategy.

item.title: ‘Almost invisible crisis’: UN urges world not to look away from Myanmar

item.title: Pope Leo calls for end to violence in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description:
During the Sunday Angelus Pope Leo appeals for those fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo to stop the violence which has broken out and return to constructive dialogue. He also remembers the newly beatified martyrs in two separate beatifications in Spain and in France on Saturday 13 December.

item.title: Pope Leo: Flowers can bloom even in prisons
item.description:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-with-mercy-forgiveness-flowers-can-bloom-even-in-prisons.html)

item.title: Challenging period ahead as flu season gathers pace
item.description: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. The flu this winter has come a few weeks early and is mainly being driven by a mutated A(H3N2) virus. Seasons that start early, tend to be more severe.

item.title: A year of 'dramatic highs and lows': 2025's 'roller-coaster ride' for the Royals
item.description: In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.
item.source:markdown:
![A person standing talks to a person seated in an elaborate chair, with a Canadian flag between them.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/10bf0528-3921-4d36-aba0-6c22dc685fbc,1765568073318/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7856%2C4419%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. item.title: Will ‘Trump Accounts’ make U.S. kids $1 million by age 28? | About That
item.description: American babies born during U.S. President Donald Trump's second term are set to receive $1,000: a gift of seed money that the government says — if contributed to maximally — will yield a return of more than $1 million by the time those children turn 28. Andrew Chang does the math to calculate the extent to which this could actually be possible and fact-checks the claim that Trump Accounts will 'jumpstart the American dream.' Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images
item.source:markdown:

American babies born during U.S. President Donald Trump's second term are set to receive $1,000: a gift of seed money that the government says — if contributed to maximally — will yield a return of more than $1 million by the time those children turn 28. Andrew Chang does the math to calculate the extent to which this could actually be possible and fact-checks the claim that Trump Accounts will 'jumpstart the American dream.'

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors debate deepening crisis in eastern DR Congo
item.description: The UN Security Council meet this morning in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. The UN Peacekeeping chief briefed on recent peace efforts – including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again – heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

item.title: UN mission’s exit marks milestone in Iraq’s post-conflict transition
item.description: After more than two decades working alongside Iraq through war, political upheaval and the fight against ISIL terrorists, the UN Assistance Mission there (UNAMI) ends its mandate on 31 December – a closure its top official describes as “honourable, dignified, and earned”.

item.title: From mud homes to joyful songs: Living heritage on the global stage
item.description: Drums and celebration filled a hall in New Delhi, India, as communities from across the world saw their traditions recognised, from Panama’s Quincha homes built by collective hands, to Yemen’s Hadrami Dan gatherings where poetry and music are created in the moment.

item.title: Peace falters as fighting in eastern DR Congo raises fears of regional war
item.description: Civilians across eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are facing collapsing health services and mass displacement as fighting spreads, undermining recent peace efforts and raising fears of a wider regional crisis.

item.title: UN environment assembly wraps up in Nairobi

item.title: Maestro Riccardo Muti set to conduct concert in Vatican
item.description:
On 12 December, world-renowned conductor Riccardo Muti performs with the Luigi Cherubini Youth Orchestra and the Choir of the Siena Cathedral “Guido Chigi Saracini” in the Vatican's Paul VI Hall. During the occasion, Muti will receive the prestigious "Ratzinger Prize," established in 2011, and awarded annually, with the Pope's approval, to eminent personalities in the field of Christian-inspired culture and art.

item.title: International Mountain Day: Preserving our tallest lifelines
item.description:
From biblical mountaintops to Ethiopia’s cliff churches, mountain regions hold deep spiritual and ecological significance, now threatened by rapid glacier loss and and a warming planet.

item.title: Gaza’s maternal and newborn health system ‘decimated’, UN warns

item.title: Canon lawyers present new standard work on child welfare
item.description:
Myriam Wijlens and Yeshica Marianne Umaña Calderón release an English-language textbook on child welfare, drawing on a long-running interdisciplinary course at the University of Erfurt. item.title: Is Trump’s stark new security strategy the end of the liberal world order? Europeans will need convincing
item.description: European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. It berates and insults them and calls into question some of the key premises of collective security that have helped protect the continent for eight decades.
item.source:markdown:
![U.S. President Donald Trump shakes hands with Russian President Vladimir Putin before a joint news conference following their meeting at Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson in Anchorage, Alaska, U.S., August 15, 2025. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5e639efb-1379-4eb7-8fde-f3059645f032,1765317835641/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C211%2C3899%2C2193%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. It berates and insults them and calls into question some of the key premises of collective security that have helped protect the continent for eight decades.

item.title: Security should be part of resilience planning - Makhlouf
item.description: The Governor of the Central Bank Gabriel Makhlouf has said Ireland needs to include security considerations in its planning for economic resilience in future.
item.source:markdown: The Governor of the Central Bank Gabriel Makhlouf has said Ireland needs to include security considerations in its planning for economic resilience in future.
